resources.string: This calculator has questionable validity, learn more

Dear Colleague,

Intervention in the course of pregnancy is always serious business. A Bishop Score can help you plan how to induce labor when you and your patient together decide induction is appropriate.

Calculators and scoring schemes are from published literature (see references). The author of the app has tried to faithfully present the findings and guidance of others with explanations and discussion while not substituting his own judgment. If you think I have erred in presentation or explanation, please let me know!

This app is no substitute for knowledge, training, and experience in labor induction. The app is merely a quick reference of material you already know.

And like any other calculator scoring scheme, these calculators suggest how you might plan induction for the average patient. But, they cannot tell you how to manage the single unique patient at hand right now. Individualize your care and be vigilant for advances and changes in induction management. And most of all, do your own thinking.

Induction of labor is a medical intervention undertaken to bring pregnancy to its conclusion with delivery before nature intended. As such, some women's bodies are more ready for labor while others are less ready. In 1964, Edward Bishop published his classic paper describing pelvic exam findings which correlated with imminence of spontaneous labor and, by extension, readiness for induced labor. His score for pelvic exam findings soon took his name as the Bishop Score. Although his study was about imminence of natural labor and not about the intervention of induction, he asserted that the score was useful for predicting which women could be induced to achieve a successful vaginal delivery. Subsequent work confirmed that pelvic findings predicted likelihood of induction success.

Over the ensuing years, other scoring systems were developed based upon pelvic exam findings and maternal characteristics such as parity, postdates, and more. The original Bishop Score and all the subsequent ones involved findings and point schemes and sometimes weighting of factors to arrive at a final score. Most if not all schemes have too many factors and point systems to memorize. Paper charts and digital calculators like those in this app are indispensable. The original Bishop Score of the 1964 paper and the Hughey 1976 critique of the several schemes of the time with its "modifiers" to improve the accuracy are both popular currently and are presented in this app. The third is the 2011 Simplified Bishop Score. Using modern statistical methods and a large sample size of nulliparas who typically provide the most challenge to induce, the Simplified Bishop seeks to achieve predictive accuracy as good or better than the original score while simplifying the number of factors involved for the sake of ease of use.

In all cases, a woman with a low score is considered "unfavorable" for induction and less likely to arrive at a vaginal delivery with Oxytocin, amniotomy, and the like. Her chances for success are improved by measures which "ripen" or prepare the cervix and produce higher scores and better readiness for subsequent induction measures. Typical ripening agents include prostaglandins and mechanical dilators like Foley catheters. When ripening agents produce improved favorable Bishop scores, induction usually commences.

But it must be noted that although various papers and guidelines cite score thresholds, these thresholds are somewhat arbitrary. The success rate difference between Bishop scores of 1 versus 7 is large, while the difference between 6 and 7 is small, even though the threshold score for favorable induction success is >6 (ACOG, 2009). There is a continuum of rates of vaginal delivery success. Furthermore, different types of patients and different situations may warrant different thresholds for who needs ripening and who may proceed to induction. Thus one should not read these calculators, their scores, and the cited success levels as absolute. Because so many papers and calculators cite thresholds and offer interpretations, these do, too. You may (and should!) substitute your own interpretations and thresholds according to your knowledge of the literature and your knowledge of your patient and her unique clinical situation as you plan induction.

Some Bishop calculators give a percent likelihood of successful vaginal delivery such as "score 2 = X%, score 3 = Y%, score 8 = Z%," etc, all based upon the stats from the source paper in the literature. But that would suggest that such numbers generalize and apply to your present patient. Given how c-section rates were dramatically different in 1964 and 1976 from 2011, and how different papers studying different populations will have different vaginal delivery rates, I think it would be misleading to cite an absolute percent likelihood of success that one would be tempted to apply to a current patient under consideration for induction. Using relative terms like "favorable" and "unfavorable", even with it's inaccuracies, is better.

Finally, do not lose sight of the fact that a Bishop score does NOT tell you whether to induce. You, the clinician, in concert with your patient's needs, wishes, and values, choose whether and when to bring pregnancy to an end and move a patient towards delivery with induction. Only when you decide to induce do you employ a Bishop score to tell you whether to ripen first.

Written to put Bishop score calculators in the hands of physicians, midwives, nurses, students, and residents at the point of care.

Content + Design:
		Joshua Steinberg MD,
		UHS Wilson Family Practice Residency,
		Binghamton NY 

Programmer:
		Anchu Lee,
		Binghamton University

Feedback: jds.pocapps@gmail.com
Platform: Android Lollipop 5.0 - Android Pie 9
Version: 1
License: GNU General Public License v3.0
Source: https://github.com/leeanchu/BishopScores

"Pelvic Scoring for Elective Induction", Edward Bishop, Obstetrics and Gynecology, vol. 24, no. 2, August 1964.

"An Evaluation of Preinduction Scoring Systems", Hughey et. al., Obstetrics and Gynecology, vol. 48, no. 6, December 1976.

"Using a Simplified Bishop Score to Predict Vaginal Delivery", Laughon et. al., Obstetrics and Gynecology, vol. 117, no. 4, April 2011.

"Induction of Labor", ACOG Practice Bulletin 107, Obstetrics and Gynecology, vol. 114, no. 2, part 1, August 2009.

In 1964 Edward Bishop's classic paper (see references) looked at the pelvic exam findings of 500 women and found correlation between 5 advancing criteria and imminence of spontaneous labor. Knowledge that spontaneous labor was near, he then asserted, also predicted which patients could successfully be induced to achieve vaginal delivery.

Ever since, the Bishop score has been used to distinguish patients who can be induced straight away from those who would need cervical ripening before induction measures. Typically one ripens the cervix until a satisfactory Bishop score is reached, and then induction commences.

Population: Bishop does not describe the characteristics of the 500 women he studied. It has been asserted that he studied mostly or all multiparous women. While the paper does not say so explicitly, Bishop does say early in his paper that induction of nulliparas should be avoided, suggesting that he viewed Bishop scoring as a tool for likely use with multiparas.

Thresholds: Bishop's paper states that a score of 9 or more portends induction success. ACOG's most recent Practice Bulletin on induction of labor (see references) states that a consensus of studies suggests that a Bishop score > 6 is favorable for success and ≥ 9 yields success rates as good as those of natural spontaneous labor. A look at the Laughon Simplified Bishop paper (see references) not only shows comparisons between the original Bishop score and the proposed new simplified score, but it also shows success rate curves for a large cohort of realworld patients, confirming that higher scores (in either scheme) are met with higher rates of success yet reminding one that thresholds are somewhat artificial as there is a continuum of rising success rates rather than clear thresholds.

In 2011, Laughon and colleagues (see references) used modern statistical methods to find which factors are associated with induction success with an eye towards trying to arrive at a scheme simpler than the classic Bishop score. From a contemporary electronic multicenter database of more than 200,000 patients they analysed the 5,600 nulliparas undergoing induction who had a full set of pelvic findings and outcomes recorded. They found that although all of the Bishop factors correlated with induction success, the factors of dilation, effacement, and station correlated the most, and the removal of cervical position and consistency did not weaken the predictive power of a simplified scoring scheme. They then validated the Simplified Bishop Score via bootstrapping (running comparative analyses of old Bishop and new Simplified Bishop schemes on large randomly selected cohorts of their original data set). The paper demonstrates statistically and then graphically that the new Simplified Bishop Score yields almost identical predictive results at each scoring level as the classic Bishop Score.

Thresholds: what score is good enough to proceed with induction with high likelihood of success? The authors of the Simplified Bishop Score paper used Bishop's own higher threshold of ≥9 to declare that success was likely. An original Bishop score ≥9 correlates statistically with a Simplified Bishop score of >5. However, one should note that ACOG's standard for a satisfactory Bishop score for favorable outcomes is >6. Careful review of Laughon's statistics and graphs shows that this lower threshold corresponds to a Simplified Bishop score of >4. Thus the app notes both the >5 and >4 thresholds as potentially meaningful to clinicians and cites them both with the score results and likelihood of success statement.

Population: it should be noted that the Simplified Bishop Score was developed only on nulliparous patients.Until validated and possibly recalibrated for a parous population, it cannot accurately be used to guide parous inductions. Although this is somewhat limiting, it is the nullipara who is most difficult to induce and thus this is the population who needs guidance on induction success the most.

Modifiers abbreviations:
Preecl = pre-eclampsia
PROM = prelabor or prolonged ROM
Elective = no medical indication for induction
Postdates & Prior Vaginal Deliveries self-explanatory

The Bishop Score with Modifiers is of such questionable validity that it should probably not guide care. I include it in this app because it is pretty popular among online website and handheld app calculators. Omitting it would leave it unaddressed, and including it allows for a discussion of the evidence. which follows.

In 1976, Hughey and colleagues (see reference) compared each of the five existing pelvic scoring systems of the day (Bishop, Fields, Burnett, Simple and Complete Friedman) by running 100 patients at his hospital through all five scoring systems and comparing each scheme's ability to predict induction success. He purposely analyzed a population of mixed parity and indications. To compare across schemes, he looked at whether scores in the lower third of each scheme predicted lowest success rates, middle third scores predicted intermediate success, and highest third scores predicted highest success. Hughey found that all scoring schemes were similarly accurate for the lower third of scores, but not so much for middle and upper thirds.

So Hughey then looked at factors which could give correction points of +1, -1, etc., and see if these "modifiers" could lead to correct classification in lower, middle, and upper thirds of scores to correspond with lower, middle, and higher rates of success. He found it worked for the Bishop score and the other four schemes. Correction points as follows:
- Nulliparous: -1
- Parous: +1 for each prior vag delivery
- Pre-eclamptic: +1
- Prelabor/prolonged ROM: -1
- Postdates: -1
- Induction purely elective: +1

Thresholds: as Hughey divided up the Bishop 0-13 score into lower (0-4 pts), middle (5-9), and upper (10-13) thirds, it is hard to know what to make of the middle third. In the study, those with a modified score 0-4 had a 50% induction failure rate, and it seems appropriate to call such a success rate unfavorable for induction. Those with a modified score 10-13 had a failure rate of 0\%, thus this group certainly seems favorable for induction. Those in the middle group with modified score 5-9 had a 10\% failure rate, which at first glance seems also favorable. But keep in mind that the overall failure rate (oddly defined as it was, see below) was 12\% and the overall c-section rate was 7\%, thus 10\% failure rate is neither better nor different than the average overall outcome, and thus can hardly be called favorable. With 40 years hindsight and a little bit of evidence based medicine statistics knowledge, I am not willing to call this middle score group anything more definitive than "intermediate" likelihood of success. If you have more insight, please let me know.

Population and critique of results: study cohort was 100 "unselected patients" over 8 months ending in July 1975, with induction indications 54 patients elective, 19 prelabor or prolonged ROM, 14 postdates, 6 pre-eclampsia, 2 known fetal demise, 2 gestational diabetes, and 1 each recurring false labor, Rh disease, and cervical incompetence with failed MacDonald procedure. Induction failure was defined as labor ending in c-section or cessation of pitocin to halt the induction. There were 12 such induction failures, 6 of whom went to c-section on first day while the other 6 were induced again the next day with 5 vaginal deliveries and 1 c-section (these days the 5 two-day inductions would be called successes). With only 12 failures as defined and 7 total c-sections, one must note that all numbers involved -- \# pts with GDM or postdates, \# induction failures, # c-sections -- all the numbers involved are SO low as to imperil the conclusions. For instance, change a single outcome associated with a factor like preeclampsia or parity or postdates and it would almost have to change the conclusions and correction point weightings given that but 12 failures (7 by today's standards) were spread among the factors analyzed. More certainty on validity or lack thereof would require raw data or statistical significance information which regrettably the paper did not offer.
Similar to a 7 in Original Bishop
